titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Anne Harney

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T18:16-0400

did.unittitle: American Physical Society and APS. Joint Committee on the History of Theoretical Physics in the Twentieth Century. Collection
did.abstract:
Primary source materials for the history of quantum physics in the twentieth century, collected under the auspices of the APS and the American Physical Society, with a grant from the National Science Foundation. There are transcripts of the oral history interviews, as well as the working papers of the Committee. These include correspondence with famous figures in physics, with some memoirs, photographs, lectures, etc. On microfilm (see
Mss. 530.1 Ar2 ) are manuscripts of Niels Henrick David Bohr and his scientific correspondence (62 reels from the Niels Bohr Archives, Universitets Institut for Teoretisk Fysik, Copenhagen). This collection is described and analyzed in Sources for the History of Quantum Physics: An Inventory and Report, by Thomas S. Kuhn, John L. Heilbron, Paul Forman, and Lini Allen (Philadelphia, 1967). The subject guide derived from the work has subsequently been digitized in its entirety and is available through the finding aid for
Mss. 530.1 Ar2.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: American Physical Society and American Philosophical Society. -- Joint Committee on the History of Theoretical Physics in the Twentieth Century.

did.unittitle: I. Transcripts of Oral History Recordings, with biographical information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In addition to written transcripts of the oral history interviews undertaken during the project, this series also includes correspondence and biographical information.
Please note: Folders without a scope and content note consist solely of biographical materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes "Relativity Seminar by A. Einstein," a lecture given by Einstein in 1954. Notes of the lecture were taken by J. A. Wheeler, and it was later edited by A. M. Jaffe in 1961. Also includes transcript of "A Talk with Einstein" by Esther Salaman, 1955.
